fr:title.text: Frame of opens of a general scheme

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Frame of opens of a general scheme

fr:mainmatter.html:p: For a scheme X, there is a bijective correspondence between its frame of opens and quasi-coherent ideals \mathrm {Idl}_Q(X) of X.

Again we prove a dual equivalence between \mathrm {Idl}_Q(X) and closed subsets of X. For any (quasi-coherent) ideal \mathcal {I} of \mathcal {O}_{X}, Construction gives us a closed subset C_{\mathcal {I}} already. Now for a closed subset Y of X, we construct an ideal \mathcal {I}_Y such that for any open U of X, \mathcal {I}_Y(U) := \{a\in \mathcal {O}_{X}(U)\mid \forall y \in Y \cap U.\ y \not \models a\}. This ideal is quasi-coherent, because if U is affine open \operatorname {Spec} A, then the intersection Y \cap \operatorname {Spec} A, in the notation of Proposition , is the closed set C_I for some ideal I of A. For any a\in A, \mathcal {I}_{Y}(\operatorname {Spec} A/a) = \{b\in A/a\mid \forall y \in C_I.\ y \not \models b\} = a \wedge I. By Proposition this means \mathcal {I}_Y is quasi-coherent.

Now if we start from a quasi-coherent ideal \mathcal {I}, to show \mathcal {I} = \mathcal {I}_{C_{\mathcal {I}}}, it suffices to show this on an affine open cover. For any affine open \operatorname {Spec} A of X, since C_{\mathcal {I}} \cap \operatorname {Spec} A is closed in \operatorname {Spec} A, it corresponds to C_I for an ideal I of A. Since \mathcal {I} is quasi-coherent, we must have \mathcal {I}(\operatorname {Spec} A) = \widetilde {I}. Hence, \mathcal {I}_{C_{\mathcal {I}}}(\operatorname {Spec} A) = \{a \in A\mid \forall y \in C_{\mathcal {I}} \cap \operatorname {Spec} A.\ y \not \models a\} = I = \mathcal {I}(\operatorname {Spec} A). This shows \mathcal {I}_{C_{\mathcal {I}}} = \mathcal {I}.

fr:title.text: Sheaf of ideals generate quasi-closed immersions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Sheaf of ideals generate quasi-closed immersions

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Now let i : C_{\mathcal {I}} \hookrightarrow X be the closed inclusion. From general topos theory, we know the direct image i_* : \mathrm {Sh}(C_{\mathcal {I}}) \to \mathrm {Sh}(X) is fully faithful, whose essentially image consists of those sheaves \mathcal {F} where \mathcal {F}_x \cong 1 for all x\in \overline {C_{\mathcal {I}}} (see e.g. Construction ). This is in particular true for the quotient sheaf \mathcal {I}/\mathcal {O}_{X}, since for any x\in \overline {C_{\mathcal {I}}}, by Lemma we have (\mathcal {I}/\mathcal {O}_{X})_x \cong \mathcal {I}_x/\mathcal {O}_{X,x} and by definition for any x\in C_{\mathcal {I}}, we know \mathcal {I}_x/\mathcal {O}_{X,x} is the trivial distributive lattice. Hence, there is an essentially unique sheaf of distributive lattices \mathcal {O}_{C_{\mathcal {I}}} where i_*\mathcal {O}_{C_{\mathcal {I}}} \cong \mathcal {I}/\mathcal {O}_{X}.

Furthermore, for any x\in C_{\mathcal {I}}, the map i^*\mathcal {O}_{X} \to \mathcal {O}_{C_{\mathcal {I}}} on stalk over x is given by the quotient \mathcal {O}_{X,x} \twoheadrightarrow \mathcal {I_x}/\mathcal {O}_{X,x} By construction this is a closed quotient of a local distributive lattice where the quotient is non-trivial. Hence, it is a morphism of locally distributed spaces, and we get a quasi-closed immersion C_{\mathcal {I}} \hookrightarrow X

Given Example , we would like a notion of sheaf of ideals, under which the closed subscheme associated to it under Construction will always be a scheme. For this we first consider the case for affine schemes. Our guiding principle is again the bijection in Proposition .

Let I be an ideal of a distributive lattice D. We construct a sheaf of ideal \widetilde {I} on \operatorname {Spec} D as follows: For any a\in D, we define \widetilde {I}(a) := a \wedge I. Evidently, a \wedge I \subseteq D/a is an ideal for all a\in D. This is a sheaf of ideals of \mathcal {O}_{D} by the same proof as proposition .

For a scheme X, we say an ideal \mathcal {I} of \mathcal {O}_{X} is quasi-coherent if for any affine open \operatorname {Spec} A of X, \mathcal {I}|_{\operatorname {Spec} A} = \widetilde {I} for some ideal I of A. We will write the poset of quasi-coherent ideals of X as \mathrm {Idl}_Q(X).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: This is evident, since the condition exactly expresses that on each affine open \operatorname {Spec} A, \mathcal {I}|_{\operatorname {Spec} A} = \widetilde {\mathcal {I}(\operatorname {Spec} A)}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: This way, we first have a generalisation for the results in Proposition .

At the end, we show that Construction when applied to quasi-coherent ideals of schemes always produces a scheme.

A quasi-closed immersion f : X \to Y is a closed immersion if the ideal sheaf \mathcal {I} with \mathcal {O}_{Y} \twoheadrightarrow f_*\mathcal {O}_{X} \cong \mathcal {I}/\mathcal {O}_{Y} is quasi-coherent on Y.

Let X be a scheme and C a closed subset of X. Let \mathcal {I} be the corresponding quasi-coherent ideal of \mathcal {O}_{X} as shown in Proposition . Then Construction makes C a scheme, with a closed immersion C \hookrightarrow X.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: The case when X is affine is clear. It is easy to see that when X = \operatorname {Spec} A and \mathcal {I} = \widetilde {I} for some ideal I of A, the closed immersion C_{\mathcal {I}} \hookrightarrow \operatorname {Spec} A is exactly \operatorname {Spec} I/A \hookrightarrow \operatorname {Spec} A induced by A \twoheadrightarrow I/A (cf. Remark ). The case for general schemes is then evident from this.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The class of closed immersions are affine admissible.

Closed immersions are evidently closed under compositions. For pullbacks, it suffices to observe that they are affine local and closed immersions of affine schemes, which corresponds to quotients of the form D \twoheadrightarrow I/D for some ideal I of D, are closed under pushouts.

Now to show it is affine local, suppose we have a morphism of schemes C \to X where for an affine open cover X = \bigcup _{i}\operatorname {Spec} A_i, the restriction C_i \to \operatorname {Spec} A_i is a closed immersion. Then C must be closed in X, and the ideal sheaf corresponding to C must be quasi-coherent, since they are quasi-coherent on each affine open. Hence, C \to X is a closed immersion.

fr:title.text: Affine schemes of integral distributive lattices are integral

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Affine schemes of integral distributive lattices are integral

fr:mainmatter.html:p: D is integral iff \operatorname {Spec} D is integral.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Suppose D is integral. By Proposition an arbitrary open subset corresponds to an ideal I. Recall from Proposition , the value \mathcal {O}_{D}(O_I) is D_I, the lattice of I-elements of D. Let u,v\in D_I with u \wedge v = 0. This means that for all i\in I, u(i) \wedge v(i) = 0. We show if u(i) \neq 0 for some i\in I, then v = 0. For any j\in I, we have v(j) \wedge u(i) \le j \wedge u(i) = u(i \wedge j). Similarly, v(j) \wedge u(i) \le v(j) \wedge i = v(i\wedge j), which implies that v(j) \wedge u(i) \le u(i \wedge j) \wedge v(i \wedge j) = (u \wedge v)(i \wedge j) = 0. Hence, since D is integral and u(i) \neq 0, we must have v(j) = 0, for all j\in I. This proves D_I is also integral.

There is a bijection of frame of opens of \operatorname {Spec} D with the frame \mathrm {Idl}(D) of ideals of D. For any ideal I, the open subset O_I it corresponds to is O_I := \{x\in \operatorname {Spec} D\mid \exists p \in I.\ x \models p\} = \bigcup _{p\in I}O_p.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: For simplicity, we construct a dual equivalence between closed sets and ideals of D. By construction, let C_p be the complement of O_p, then the closed set C_I corresponding to I is given by C_I = \overline {O_I} = \bigcap _{p\in I}C_p. On the other hand, given any closed set C we construct an ideal I_C := \{p\in D\mid \forall x\in C.\ x \not \models p\}. Verification is routine.
